title: Ticket #2205: PERMISSION DENIED to unauthenticated@unmapped from host <garbage>
description:
The current master (targetting 7.7.0) occasionally writes log messages that look like this: 
06/01/11 18:12:56 PERMISSION DENIED to unauthenticated@unmapped from host ������(���������������
This is obviously bad.

Investigation:

1: gdb refuses to debug these binaries for me. It eventually fails with {code} Detaching after fork from child process 3232. warning: Can't attach LWP -1: No such process ../../gdb/linux-thread-db.c:389: internal-error: thread_get_info_callback: Assertion `inout->thread_info != NULL' failed. A problem internal to GDB has been detected, further debugging may prove unreliable. Quit this debugging session? (y or n) {endcode} I haven't dug deeper to see if my system is hosed or what.

  1. The code in question (DaemonCore::Verify /src/condor_daemon_core.V6/daemon_core.cpp line 2903) is this: 
    		char ipstr[IP_STRING_BUF_SIZE];
		addr.to_ip_string(ipstr, sizeof(ipstr));
	//sin_to_ipstring(sin,ipstr,IP_STRING_BUF_SIZE);

			// Note that although this says D_ALWAYS, when the result is
			// ALLOW, we only get here if D_SECURITY is on.
		dprintf( D_ALWAYS,
				 "PERMISSION %s to %s from host %s for %s, "
				 "access level %s: reason: %s\n",
				 result_desc,
				 (fqu && *fqu) ? fqu : "unauthenticated user",
				 ipstr,
				 command_descrip ? command_descrip : "unspecified operation",
				 PermString(perm),
				 reason->Value() );
    printf debugging reveals that inside addr.to_ip_string, everything is working fine. just befor to_ip_string returns, ipstr contain a valid address, indeed it's the IP address for the local host (probably a child process). However, as soon as to_ip_string returns, everything is trashed.
remarks:
2011-Jun-01 20:50:53 by nwp:
The fact that data seems to be being overwritten points to a buffer overflow somewhere, I think. Maybe gdb is giving up because it cannot find the stack frame. My shot from the hip for the day.

2011-Jun-02 12:04:11 by adesmet:
  • Rebuilding from scratch, Just In Case
  • Will retry GDB, this time with "USE_CLONE_TO_CREATE_PROCESSES = false", which I forgot. (Surprised that the failure case is an internal GDB error)
  • psilord proposes turning off -O2 on the files in question. Will try.

2011-Jun-02 12:55:30 by adesmet:
  • GDB problem: fixed by turning off cloning.
  • Garbage output: Immediate cause: Code path was asked to convert an invalid sockaddr_in struct into a string. New question: why are invalid sockaddr_ins reaching this point. Digging...

2011-Jun-02 13:33:50 by adesmet:
ReliSock::accept(ReliSock &c) (/src/condor_io/reli_sock.cpp line 182) modifies c._sock directly. As a result, c never becomes aware that it needs to rebuild c._who with the correct peer information. Correct solution is probably to instead call c.assign() (which also happily eliminates the need to call c.move_descriptor_up()).

2011-Jun-02 14:04:32 by adesmet:
Worth noting: the PERMISSION DENIED errors are probably because the permission system failed because the IP addresses were invalid.

check_ins: 2011-Jun-02 14:00   Check-in [22092]: Don't monkey around with another object's member variables; you circumvent important code. Not even if you're the same class. Assigning the file descriptor for a ReliSock should always go through ReliSock::asign. Failure to do so means any attempt to call ReliSock::get_peername will fail. [...] (By Alan De Smet )
